head.title: Ode to Columbus.11 Published in City Gazette and Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (Supplement, March 5, 1796), p. 1. Possibly written as a prologue for one of the patriotic theatrical performances repeated yearly by the Charleston, SC theatre companies.

lg.l: While Greece and Rome, renown’d in ancient song,
In ruins lie; and Europe’s boasted realms,
The muses’ favor’d seats, begin to nod
And totter to their fall: the tuneful maids22 The nine muses.
Explore more happy climes, and hail the shores
Of fair Columbia,33 Poetic name in use since the 1730s for the original Thirteen Colonies of the United States. where celestial Peace
And God-like Freedom reign; a heavenly pair,
Who with benignant smile invite from far
The exil’d sisters; who, beneath the shade
Of their auspicious olive, tune the lyre
And pour the sacred song. Then say, ye nine,
What theme’s more worthy of the trembling string,
Than him who first explor’d the western main,
Undaunted measur’d seas unknown before,
And gave this infant world to human ken?
Or him, who when oppression rais’d the sword,
And bade fell discord rage, espous’d her cause,
And crown’d her rising states with lasting peace?
What names can more the poets numbers claim?
Then raise the song of triumph to their fame!
When from the ports of ancient Spain
Columbus first his sails unfurl’d,
The sea-green Neiades44 Water nymphs. in his train
Thus cheer’d him midst the watry world:
Hail, great Columbus! Succeeding times shall see
A new creation rais’d by thee.
Thou shalt the happy land behold
Where lavish plenty laughs around,
Her trees surcharg’d with fruits of gold,
Fields with spontaneious harvest crown’d.
Hail, great Columbus! succeeding times shall see
A new creation rais’d by thee.
There arts and industry shall rise;
The swelling canvas commerce bend;
there cities spires shall reach the skies,
and walls and lofty tow’rs ascend.
Hail, great Columbus! succeeding times shall see
A new creation rais’d by thee.
Proud royalty with iron sway
Shall impious mask her growing gains,
To make her colonies obey,
Presumptuous forge despotic chains.
Hail, great Columbus! succeeding times shall see
A new creation rais’d by thee.
But Freedom, guardian of the land,
In her right hand the hero brings,
By Heav’n appointed to command,
And curb the insolence of kings.
Hail, great commander! succeeding times shall see
Their guardian genius still in thee.
So long as Phoebus55 God of light, or the sun. gilds the morn,
And Cynthia66 Derived from Mount Cythus of Delos island on which the Greek goddess of the moon, Artemis was born. cheers the ev’ning hours,
While smiling plenty fill her horn
And Flora decks the earth with flow’rs;
So long, great Columbus! thy happy land shall be
The seat of Peace and Liberty.
